repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Coastal Cities Environmental
            Sanitation Project; and Global Environment Fund
            (GEF)-Coastal Cities Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Coastal Cities
            Environmental Sanitation Project; and Global Environment
            Fund (GEF)-Coastal Cities Project for Vietnam were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            for public sewerage systems, Household (HH) connections are
            essential components to ensure that most of the organic
            loading is conveyed to the treatment facility and sufficient
            flow is maintained for the system to function properly.
            Connection to the HH was an issue in the past because
            tertiary lines were not extended close to the HHs, thereby
            imposing heavy financial burden on HHs if they attempted to
            connect. All coastal cities in Vietnam had weak soil
            formation and hence, construction methods are critical to
            minimize the damages to existing structures located near
            deep excavation sites. Damages could be reduced if the scope
            of land acquisition at the start of work is determined
            taking into account the soil foundation factor. Related to
            this, as the land management system in Vietnam is still
            weak, identification of land ownership and land use history
            should be more accurate to avoid ongoing complaints from the
            affected people. Vietnam has quite a number of medium-sized
            cities that are growing fast and looking for an intervention
            on environmental sanitation. The rational question to raise
            here would be whether a programmatic approach for this
            situation will fit better rather than the traditional single
            investment lending for each city. Urban environmental
            sanitation intervention is highly contextual and varies
            widely from city to city (characteristic of waste,
            differences in urban economy, land, sources of waste, and
            others). Both approaches have their own pros and cons and
            opening up wider consultation and debate will help arrive at
            a more informed and sustainable instrument.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Coastal Cities Environment And
            Sanitation Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Coastal Cities Environment and Sanitation Project for
            Vietnam, which improves environmental sanitation,
            anticipates negative environmental risks and proposes
            measures to mitigate them. These measures during
            construction include the following: To alleviate noise,
            odor, litter, and dust, control noise levels in residential
            areas; apply dust suppression measures; avoid overloading of
            trucks; absorb and collect spills, sludge, oils and
            lubricants from equipment; sprinkle water in streets; keep
            streets clear of mud, dirt, spillage, and waste; and
            immediately remove materials and liquids causing offensive
            odors. To reduce impacts from waste, collect solid household
            and commercial wastes, and dredged or excavated material and
            transport them to approved landfill; contaminated wastes
            shall be transported separately to an approved site; store
            no waste on site for more than 24 hours; and avoid
            discharging water to land or public areas. Landowners will
            be compensated for any damage, and contractor will not sever
            or interfere with utility services. Regarding health and
            safety, provide workers with protective clothing and masks,
            safety equipment and tools, and clean water for washing; and
            maintain safe public access through sites for residents.
            Transport routes, vehicles and loads will be distributed so
            as to avoid damaging roads and bridges; and avoid use of
            tracked vehicles on paved roads. Schedule work to avoid
            night and weekend hours. During operation of the drainage
            and sewerage systems, maintain regular visual inspections of
            road conditions, new drainage systems, solid waste
            collection, public toilets, and solid waste transfer
            stations for problems needing repair; follow operational and
            safety standards; transport dredged material in covered
            vehicles to disposal site; replant trees on embankments of
            the open drainage canal to strengthen these structures,
            reduce air pollution, and enhance the local landscape.
            Chlorinate untreated effluents to reduce pathogens, screen
            outlets to remove solids, and increase water quality monitoring.
